Camp Dodge is on the slope of a prominent ridge on the west side of Des Moines River about 10 miles northwest of the business center of Des Moines, Iowa. This ridge, which extends southeastward through the camp reservation, is 150 to 200 feet high and about a mile wide, though in some places its crest is so narrow that it affords scarcely more room than is required for the road that traverses it from end to end. An observer standing on this ridge will see on the east, seemingly at his feet, Des Moines River swinging in graceful curves across its valley, which is here about a mile wide and is bounded by steep wooded slopes cut by many short ravines. East of this valley is a broad upland prairie, which stands at about the same height as the ridge in the camp, shows an even sky line, and is dotted with several villages. Turning to the west the observer may see spreading before him the broad valley of Beaver Creek, which has smooth and gentle slopes and a nearly flat bottom. The long, gentle slope from the bottom of this valley to the crest of the ridge on its east side affords an excellent location for the main buildings of Camp Dodge, and a terrace on the west side of the valley is utilized for a remount station. West of Beaver Valley is another broad upland prairie, which is similar to that east of the Des Moines and stands at about the same height.
The valley of Beaver Creek extends from northwest to southeast

One of these glaciers is believed to have invaded Iowa and melted away again before the ancient valley of Des Moines River was formed. The large size of this valley and its smooth, worn-down slopes are some indications of the length of time that the country was free from ice.

the Raccoon River valley, though probably measured in centuries, may have been relatively short, as no great terminal ridge of drift was formed along its southern margin. If the climate is just warm enough to melt the ice at the front of a glacier as fast as it advances the front remains in one position, and if this balance is maintained for a considerable time the material let down by the melting ice and deposited by streams that flow under, within, and upon the glacier accumulates in a great dump, called a moraine.
There is considerable Wisconsin drift in the ancient river valley east of Capitol Hill and Highland Park, but it is not piled up to form conspicuous hills. As the ice melted and the glacial front gradually receded, drift was left spread smoothly over valley, slope, and upland. \Y hen the receding glacial margin reached the vicinity of Camp Dodge, however, it became nearly stationary for a time long enough to permit the accumulation of a moraine, which now forms a belt of knolls and hills that extend westward from the northern part of Camp Dodge, across the bottom of Beaver Creek valley, up the gentle slope, and on westward across the upland in Grant Township. The sharply rounded profiles of these hills contrast strongly with the smoother, more gentle curves of the adjacent upland and valley slopes. The moraine is best developed in Grant Township, Dallas County, and typical morainic hills may be seen near Ingersoll station, on the Chicago, Milwaukee & St. Paul Railway, midway between Grimes and Granger. Other morainic hills occur in the western part of Jefferson Township, Polk County, and the terrace on which the remount station is built and the ridge on which the base hospital stands are evidently eastward continuations of this moraine. The morainic belt is not very clearly marked on the map, but to it are due some of the irregularities of the contour lines that mark the border of the south slope of Beaver Creek valley. The marshes and ponds in the valley west of Camp Dodge lie in hollows resulting from uneven deposition or irregular settling of the morainal drift.
When the Wisconsin glacier melted it left the valley of Des Moines River partly filled with glacial drift. The floods of water from the melting ice also carried down the valley a great quantity of sand and gravel, some of which was deposited in the neighborhood of Camp Dodge. When the glacial waters ceased to flow down the valley the river began cutting into these deposits, and now remnants of them form terraces at the sides of the valley and in a few places extend out on the bottoms. There are several small remnants of gravel terraces in sec. 25, R. 25 W., and secs. 30 and 31, R. 24 W., of

West of Des Moines River vallev, within the area covered bv the map, the prairie plain is best represented by the long, flat top of the ridge west of Grimes, which extends as far south as Walnut Creek. West of the headwaters of Walnut Creek the plain rises 1,060 feet or more above sea level. North of Beaver Creek vallev the long, gentle slopes rise to the ridge that forms the divide between Des Moines River and Beaver Creek. The upland is prairie; the steeper valley slopes are partly cleared but largely wooded.
The region south of Raccoon River valley as shown on the map by the crowded contour lines, is rough and hilly. This region is part of the Kansan drift plain, and as it has been subject to erosion for a very long time its surface is much cut up by valleys, little of the original upland plain remaining, portion of this surface shown on the map is near the main valleys, and the number and the depth of ravines and small valleys here are not notably greater than in some similar places farther north. The slight erosion of the Wisconsin drift plain as a whole, however, contrasts strongly with the great erosion of the Kansan drift in southern and western Iowa, which has been so much dissected by streams that scarcely a square mile of the original upland remains at any one place. South of Raccoon River valley the loess lies at the surface and forms the soil except where it has been washed off the slopes and into the valleys or where it is overlain or replaced by fine sand. Both loess and sand have been blown up in large part from the river flats to the north. The loess is at some places 30 feet or more thick; at other places it is much thinner or absent. Under the loess and the sand lies the Kansan drift, a pebbly, sticky clay, only the rusty, yellowish, weathered part of which is seen in exposures in this vicinity. The thickness of the Kansan drift differs widely from place to place and ranges from practically nothing to 100 feet or more.
The Wisconsin drift is a pebbly clay, which in its upper few feet is weathered yellow but farther down retains its original grayish color. It is thinner than the Kansan drift, and though its thickness differs widely at different points the maximum is probably not much over 50 feet. At some places in Camp Dodge only a foot or two of the yellow pebbly Wisconsin drift clay lies over the shale that forms
On the ridge, however, the drift Before the advance of the Wisconsin glacier the surface had been exposed for a long time to erosion by rain and streams, which had removed much material. Hence the Wisconsin drift lies in some places on loess, in others on Kansan drift, and in still others on shale.
Ever since the Wisconsin glacier melted away successive generations of plants have been growing upon the surface of the plain. Their roots have burrowed into the clay and have loosened and lightened its texture. Their stems and leaves, falling on its surface, have decayed, and at least a part of their substance has returned to the ground whence it came. By these and other processes, which have gone on for thousands of years, the upper foot or two of the drift clay has been blackened and made more fertile, so that it forms an exceedingly rich soil and has given the Iowa prairies wide fame for their productiveness. Many fine farms may be seen from the ridge back of Camp Dodge or near the limits of the reservation. In this region, naturally, general farming has been practiced to the greatest extent, with corn and oats, cattle and hogs as the most valuable products. Market gardening near the city has also proved profitable.

ORIGIN OF THE VALLEYS AND UPLANDS.
Changes in the earth’s surface.—The geologic history of this area is complex, and the changes which have taken place here are many and varied. The bedrock controls the form of the present valleys and uplands only in minor respects, and it will not be described in detail. The bedrock formations, which are exposed at some places on the sides of the valleys and which are penetrated by mines and by many wells, are the nearly flat-lying coal beds and accompanying shale, limestone, and sandstone of the coal measures. The muds and sands of which these rocks were originally composed were deposited many millions of years ago in the waters of rivers, lakes, or seas, and the beds of coal were formed in great swamps by the growth of many generations of water-loving plants. These plants, instead of decaying after they died, as wood does in the air, were preserved by the water into which they fell. The beds of material thus formed were finally covered by mud or sand, and in time all these deposits were consolidated and transformed into layers of coal, shale, sandstone, and limestone.

It is a great open trough almost as deep as the valley of Des Moines River where that stream crosses the camp reservation and nearly twice as broad, but it contains no river that corresponds to it in size, for Beaver Creek is only a small and insignificant stream that wanders through the bottom land. Most streams flow in valleys which they themselves have made and which are proportionate in size to the streams that made them, bift here the larger stream flows in the smaller valley. From a viewpoint near the south end of the ridge may be seen, to the southeast, beyond the hills of Highland Park, the gleaming dome of the Capitol, towering above Capitol Hill, and east of those high points what appears to be the continuation of Beaver Creek valley extending southeastward past the city. At length the climate again became cold, and another glacier, known as the Kansan ice sheet, spread over Iowa. For a long period, probably many hundreds or thousands of years, the region lay buried beneath the Kansan glacier before the climate again became warm enough to melt away the vast sheet of ice. When it in turn disappeared it left a heavy mantle of drift on valleys, slopes, and uplands, and during the ensuing warmer period plants and animals came back, streams began to cut away the land, and some of the larger features of the present landscape were formed. At this time occurred the notable change in the course of Des Moines River. That part of the ancient valley of Des Moines River which is now occupied by Beaver Creek and the part east of Highland Park and Capitol Hill, though not wholly obliterated, had been so deeply filled with drift that Des Moines River, when it was reestablished, took a new course and began to cut that part of its present valley which lies above the mouth of Raccoon River. (See fig. 5.)

Little is known of the conditions which prevailed here just after the coal-forming period, but it is believed that this region and all the rest of Iowa was land. On every land surface certain natural forces are more or less constantly at work loosening and wearing away the soil and rock and carrying the material down to the sea. of these forces is running water. Each rain as it dashes on the ground sweeps away some material and forms gullies, which in time are enlarged to ravines and valleys. In such of these hollows as become deep enough the underground water issues in springs that form permanent streams, which continue the work of excavation. By this process a smooth plain may in time be changed to a region of deep and intricately branching valleys separated by hills and ridges, and only on the higher of these ridges may remnants of the original
city west of Highland Park and Capitol Hill.

Des Moines, the capital of Iowa and the largest city in the State, with a population of 105,000, contains many interesting buildings, preeminent among which, probably, is the beautiful and stately Capitol, whose magnificent gilded dome is visible for miles around. Among the other public buildings in the city are the Court House and the City Hall, which are likewise notable for their architectural
beauty. Des Moines has also a fine system of parks.

One of the oldest valleys in this region is that occupied by Beaver Creek. This valley is older than the part of the valley of Des Moines River that lies above the mouth of Raccoon River, as might be inferred from their relative sizes and the character of their side slopes. The map shows that the broad valley of the Des Moines below the city and the broad lowland east of Capitol Hill and Highland Park are of about the same width as the valley of Beaver Creek and are in direct line with it. All three are in fact parts of one and the same valley, the original valley of Des Moines River. (See fig. 4.) Long ago Des Moines River flowed down what is now the valley of Beaver Creek and a small tributary valley may have been formed east of the ridge, where Des Moines River now flows, but there was no large valley such as that which now includes the eastern part of the camp reservation. CLIMATE. WATER SUPPLY, AND C0AV
rue climate^of the Camp Dodge region is marked by great Aviations between the seasons, although the annual average is nearly uniform. The range in temperature from summer to winter is about 125° F.
average temperature for the year is about 49°. The rainfall, though occasionally so great as to cause some inconvenience, is never so excessive as to bring disaster to the community. The annual average for the region for a long period is 32.5 inches, or about an inch above the average for the State as a whole. There have never been serious droughts.
Rainfall is the source, directly or indirectly, of the water supply of the region. The ground Avater—that Avhich is contained in pores and cracks in the soil and drift and rock—is derived from the rainfall either of the immediate locality or of more distant regions, and it feeds the springs and streams. Des Moines River is affected in only a slight degree by the rainfall of the Camp Dodge region, as it and Raccoon River head much farther north, but the smaller streams are dependent on the local rainfall, and it is sufficient to keep them flawing, except in their upper courses, the year round. In the earLy years of the settlement of this locality abundance of water could be obtained from wells only a few feet deep. With the increase in cultivation, hoAvever, has come a lowering of the ground-water level, so that Avells must iioav be dug deeper. The early Avells derived their supply from the upper part of the drift, from the loess, or from beds of sand or givel in the drift or in the valleys. Recent wells have been sunk a hundred to several hundred feet to reach the lower part of the drift or the beds of sandstone in the shale that underlies the drift. A Avell in Greenwood Park, Des Moines, Avas sunk 3,000 feet to reach deeper-lying sandstones that carry abundant supplies

Such deposits, Avhich are well exposed at many localities about Camp Dodge, constitute Avhat is knoAvn as glacial drift, because they Avere brought into this region by a succession of great sheets of moving ice or glaciers from the north. The glaciers Avere formed in Avhat is called the Great Ice Age, or the glacial period. During this period the heat in summer was not sufficient to melt all the snow that fell in the preceding winter, so snow accumulated from year to year, especially in central and eastern Canada, and gradually became compacted to ice. In time the ice became so thick that, spreading under its own weight, it formed vast slowly moving sheets or glaciers. The last of the great glaciers in Iowa melted aAvay probably 10,000 to 20,000 years or more ago, yet the amount of land carving done by the streams in the region of Camp Dodge since that time is relatively small — not nearly so much as that done by the streams on the Kansan drift south of Raccoon RHer. Even Des Moines River has barely begun to wash away the Wisconsin drift that Avas left in its valley. The ravines are short, and the creek valleys become
sheets invaded Iowa at different times during this interval. One of them (the Illinoian glacier) encroached on southeastern IoAva from Illinois, and a later one (the Iowan glacier) invaded northeastern Iowa from the north. (See fig. 3.) Neither of these glaciers seems to have reached this vicinity. During much of this time Des Moines River and its tributaries were wearing down their valleys and dissecting the Kansan drift plain and rain and frost and vegetation Avere forming soil from the upper part of the Kansan drift.
Not long after the Iowan glaciation of the northeastern part of the State there came a time Avhen great dust storms swept over the country, blowing much fine material from the mud flats along the rivers and from the surface of the Iowan drift. The dust was swept back and forth and lodged here and there on wooded slopes and even among the grasses of the prairie uplands. These dust storms ✓ continued until hills, valleys, and uplands in much of the region were mantled with a loose, fine buff clay known as loess (pronounced lurss with the r obscure). South of the Raccoon River valley and also east and west of this district the loess forms the subsoil over a great extent of country. It ranges in thickness from a few feet to more than 50 feet. North of the Raccoon Valley the loess is not found at the surface because it is covered by a later deposit of glacial drift. It is, however, often encountered in excavations at places where the later drift is thin. Thus at several points in Camp Dodge the loess was reached in ditches and other excavations along the slope of Beaver Creek valley, where it underlies 2 to 4 feet of pebbly glacial clay; the loess itself is free from pebbles. A well on top of the ridge near the northeastern part of the camp reservation penetrated more than 27 feet of loess beneath 25 feet of pebbly drift clay and 8 feet of sand.
One of the best exposures of the loess in this region Avas afforded by a big cut made a feAV years ago on the Chicago, Mihvaukee & St. Paul Railway at the east line of Story County, about 30 miles northeast of Camp Dodge, Avhere it lies between tAvo deposits of glacial drift. (See fig. 6.) From such an exposure much of the geologic history of central Iowa can be read. The fact that the loess overlies weathered and eroded Kansan drift on slopes and in valleys as Avell as on uplands shoAvs that it Avas deposited long after the Kansan ice had melted away—so lon£, in fact, that the Kansan drift had been weathered for many feet beloAV the surface and deep valleys had been cut into it. The further fact that in the area north of the Raccoon River valley the loess is in turn buried beneath glacial drift shoAvs that its deposition was folloAved by the invasion of another ice sheet.
The upper drift, which is fresh looking and but little weathered, lies at the £#rface or immediately below the top soil throughout north-central Iowa as far south as Des Moines. It Avas left by a fifth glacier (the Wisconsin), which invaded Iowa and spread over the upper Des Moines River valley as illustrated in figure 3. The ice of the Wisconsin glacier was probably not so thick as that of the Kansan glacier, for it did not extend so far south as the Kansan by scores of miles. HoweA^er, even within a feAV miles of its edge the frontal slope of the ice probably rose much higher than the dome of the Capitol at Des Moines. To the south lay open country ; to

Some of the deeper Avells furnish water that is highly mineralized, but the Avaters from shallOAver Avells in valley gravels or loess and drift are not objectionable on this account.
Next to farming the most important industry Avhich is dependent on natural resources in the Camp Dodge region is coal mining. Coal beds underlie much of the area shown on the map, and mines have been opened at numerous places. Several are being operated in Des Moines and others at and near Saylor, Enterprise, Berwick, and High Bridge. The coal is fairly soft but of good quality and occurs in a number of beds at different levels in the shales and sandstones. Some of the beds are too thin to be Avorked; those being mined range from 31 to 5 feet or more in thickness. The district shown on the map, which includes the mining regions of Polk and Dallas counties, produced in 1917 nearly 2,500,000 tons, more than one-fourth of all the coal mined in the State.

THE PRAIRIE PLAIN.

The prairie plain or upland of the Camp Dodge region is the southern part of the extensive plain which was covered by the Wisconsin glacier (fig. 3) and which stretches across northern IoAva and Minnesota and far into Canada. The map shows that in general the plain in this district is nearly flat, and flatness is one of its striking characteristics farther north. From any point of view in the vicinity of the few main valleys it stretches away mile after mile to the horizon, broken only here and there by a Ioav SAvell or by a shallow SAvale which is occupied by a marsh or along Avhich winds some sluggish stream. fKS SEEM BY THE GREEH GUIDE
SUMMER OUTINGS IN THE BLACK HILLS
By George S. Clason
\
In the southwest corner of the State of South Dakota lie the Black Hills, one of the most fascinating playgrounds in America. The name “Black Hills” is a misnomer. These are mountains, rugged, well timbered and beautiful. They occupy an area about sixty by one hundred miles.
For unknown generations previous to the coming of the white man, the Cheyenne Indians guarded this district and preserved it for their own great hunting ground. They had a little Monroe Doctrine of their own. If another Indian tribe poached on their preserve they did not wait on diplomacy, but started after scalps.
HERE PRECIOUS METALS HIDE
In theses rugged mountains are some of the great mines of the world. The mining camps of Deadwood and Lead have made many millionaires. The output is principally gold, but silver, lead, iron, copper, tin, tungsten and mica are also mined here.
J
FROM THESE BLACK FORESTS COME
THE NAME
I
* <3
r *
C*
The great natural forests of the Black Hills have been the basis of an important lumber industry for many years. The entire district is now included in two National For-ests, the Black Hills National Forest and the Harney National Forest. At the present time the Government controls the cutting of 4' timber on all land not privately owned. This guarantees the preservation of the natural beauty and attractiveness of the region.
Under Government supervision only timber of a certain size can be logged, and general cutting over

3 Hot Springs, South Dakota. The Battle Mountain Sanitarium
Is Shown on Top of the Hill
is not allowed. Camping and picnicking is encouraged in the National Forests.
A PARADISE FOR THE AUTO TOURIST
A more delightful place for the summer tour could not be imagined. Here will be found a climate clear and equable—cool nights all summer long, with days sunny but not hot. Good main trunk highways will be found between the principal towns. There are innumerable camping spots beside cool trout streams and beneath the sheltering spruce and pines.
HUNTING AND FISHING FOR THE SPORT LOVER
The Black Hills country is traversed by many excellent trout streams. Brook trout, rainbow and salmon trout can be caught here.
There are deer, wolves, silver foxes, coyotes, wild cats and an occasional bear is to be found, with a more generous supply of duck, partridge and rabbits.
THE RESORT TOWN OF HOT SPRINGS
Many people come to Hot Springs to receive benefit from the medicinal waters of the springs, there being over one hundred thermal springs. Others come just to have a good time, to enjoy the climate and to do the many points of scenic and historic interest nearby. It is a good place to stop. Not an ultra-fashionable place, but one with good hotel accommodations and good bathing facilities, including several fine large pools.
The springs have medicinal qualities that make them invaluable for rheumatism, nervous complaints, indigestion t
and intestinal disorders, pulmonary afflictions, diseases of the urinary organs, gout and skin diseases. The cures of rheumatism, muscular, sciatic and inflammatory, are frequently marvelous.
The U. S. Government has built here the Battle Mountain Sanitarium for disabled soldiers and sailors. Honorably discharged officers, soldiers and sailors suffering from diseases that can be benefited by the mineral waters, and having no adequate means of support, are taken care of while undergoing treatments. Admission is by application only, which should be made by mail to the Surgeon, Battle Mountain Sanitarium, Hot Springs, S. D.
THE WIND CAVE NATIONAL PARK
Twelve miles north of the town of Hot Springs is Wind Cave, one of the world’s greatest and most beautiful natural caverns. Here beneath the ground over one hundred miles of passages and three thousand chambers have been explored, and still the extent of this cavern can only be guessed at.
The Fair Grounds chamber, with its various galleries, is said to be the largest natural underground chamber in the world. It covers an area between four and five acres, the height being from ten to forty feet.
The cavern is ornamented with characteristic stalagmites, stalactites, geodes, peculiar box-work formations and lace-like crystals. The name Wind Cave comes from the rush of air that goes in and out, caused by the varying atmospheric pressure.
There are regular trips through the cave for visitors, in charge of trustworthy guides.
Wind Cave is now one of our National Parks.
The Wind Cave Game Preserve is located in the park.
One of the Large Mining Properties That Will Be Found Around Lead and Deadwood
5 Pickerel Lake Is Well Named and All That the Name Implies
Here can be seen herds of buffalo, elk and antelope living and breeding in natural surroundings.
THE JEWEL CAVE NATIONAL MONUMENT
This cavern is located thirteen miles west of Custer in the Black Hills National Forest. It is reached by a good auto road. The main passage is open to visitors for one and a half miles, where is crosses Milk River; an underground stream with water the color of milk. Like Wind Cave, it is composed of many chambers beautifully orna-.mented with lime crystals.	i
OTHER THINGS WORTH SEEING AROUND THE
BLACK HILLS	s
The Bad Lands, forty miles east of Hot Springs, are undeniably ugly, but nevertheless interesting. Here underlying coal veins burned and left a country unfit for vegetation. Wind, rain and snow have chiseled the face of the rocks and the earth into weird, uncanny shapes and forms.
The abundance of fossils, agates, crystals and beautiful stones is unusual.
On Battle Mountain can still be seen the rough fortifications built by the Cheyenne Indians many years ago when they fought a decisive battle with their mortal enemies, the Sioux.
At Cascade Springs, only nine miles from Hot Springs, will be found attractive scenery and many mineral springs.
One giant spring, the Big Geyser, pours forth a barrel of water every second.
6 Sylvan Lake, six miles from Custer, is a peiTect gem of the mountains.
The United States Bureau of Fisheries has an important fish hatchery at Spearfish. This is an interesting and instructive place to visit.
Between Hermosa and Custer is the State Game Preserve, enclosing 61,440 acres in a woven wire fence eight feet high and forty mils long. Here are herds of buffalo, elk, deer, antelope and other native game.
Near Belle Fourche can be seen the great dam and lake built by the U. S. Reclamation Service, from which 50,000 acres of land have been irrigated.
The Belle Fourche National Bird Preserve occupies the lands immediately adjoining the reservoir, covering 90,000 acres. Here in spring and autumn may be seen great flocks of duck and other water fowl which stop on their migration for rest and refuge.
SOUTH DAKOTA, THE AGRICULTURAL EMPIRE
This is a state with much undeveloped land. It has room for many new farmers to till its fertile soil. The present population of 635,839 could be increased many times without overcrowding the millions of acres of prairie land.
Already South Dakota has forged ahead to a high rank among the agricultural states of the Nation. Each year the total production, by states, of farm crops vary. First one state leads, then another. It is safe to say that you can always find South Dakota, notwithstanding her small population, as ranking about fourth in the production of the two great staple grain crops, corn and wheat.
Among the many other farm products that are successfully raised in the state can be mentioned oats, barley,

Here can be seen herds of buffalo, elk and antelope living and breeding in natural surroundings.
THE JEWEL CAVE NATIONAL MONUMENT
This cavern is located thirteen miles west of Custer in the Black Hills National Forest. It is reached by a good auto road. The main passage is open to visitors for one and a half miles, where is crosses Milk River; an underground stream with water the color of milk. Like Wind Cave, it is composed of many chambers beautifully orna-.mented with lime crystals.
OTHER THINGS WORTH SEEING AROUND THE
BLACK HILLS
The Bad Lands, forty miles east of Hot Springs, are undeniably ugly, but nevertheless interesting. Here underlying coal veins burned and left a country unfit for vegetation. Wind, rain and snow have chiseled the face of the rocks and the earth into weird, uncanny shapes and forms. The abundance of fossils, agates, crystals and beautiful stones is unusual.
On Battle Mountain can still be seen the rough fortifications built by the Cheyenne Indians many years ago when they fought a decisive battle with their mortal enemies, the Sioux.
At Cascade Springs, only nine miles from Hot Springs, will be found attractive scenery and many mineral springs. One giant spring, the Big Geyser, pours forth a barrel of water every second.
6 Oats, One of South Dakota’s Staple Crops. Note the Fine Improvements on This Farm
speltz, flax, alfalfa, millet, clover, timothy, potatoes, garden vegetables, fruits and berries.
South Dakota is a great agricultural state, a great stock raising and dairying state, and it is going to be still greater. The comparatively low value placed on much of the good prairie land and the wonderfully productive soil are constantly bringing new settlers to the state, who appreciate the wonderful opportunities offered to grow up and prosper with the development of a new country.
INTERESTING FACTS ABOUT SOUTH DAKOTA
The eastern portion is a comparatively level prairie, slightly rolling in the central portion, and raising into foothills around the Black Hills.
The soil in the greater part of the state is a black loam overlaying a deep clay subsoil. It is rich in the essential elements of plant food.
The average rainfall is 21.59 inches, of which 17 inches falls during the growing season. This means a dry harvest time and usually very little winter snow.
The total land surface is 76,868 square miles. Its length east and west is 360 miles, width 240.
The state flower is the Pasque.
Pierre is the state capital. The population, according to the 1920 census, is 635,839.
In the northwestern part of the state are large areas underlaid with lignite coal veins. Deposits of the following minerals also occur in commercial quantities, but so far are more or less undeveloped: Spodumen, amblygonite, fullers earth, volcanic ash, clay, cement, lime, building stone.
The highest elevation is Harney Peak, 7,240 feet, and the lowest Big Stone Lake, 967 feet.

MAP UP blUUA. PALLS BUSiJNILSS DISTRICT Showing Location of Depots, Hotels and Public Buildings. Not All of South Dakota’s Gold Mines Are to be Found in the Black Hills. Here is a Wheat Yield That Would be a Gold Mine
in Any Country
The people of South Dakota are industrious, thrifty, prosperous and 85 per cent American-born.
South Dakota has modern, up-to-date schools and colleges, with a school fund of $14,000,000 to guarantee their support and progress.
FREE INFORMATION ABOUT SOUTH DAKOTA
The South Dakota Department of Immigration, Pierre, S. D., will gladly furnish information about land, manufacturing and business opportunities in the state.
GOOD ROADS IN SOUTH DAKOTA
The black sandy loam soil of South Dakota prairies, when properly graded, makes a splendid highway, except in the most extremely wet weather. The good roads problem has been much easier to solve here than in most localities because machinery can be used to a large extent for road building.
In 1912 a great impetus was given to highway construction by the projection of several trunk highways across the state, some east and west, others north and south. These roads connect with the main transcontinental highways. The work of improving them has been kept up continuously. Much of their length is now gravel surfaced, and they are all thoroughly posted.
Splendid wide roads have been built through the Black Hills to connect the principal towns. The stranger touring across South Dakota will find “the going good.”
An energetic State Highway Commission, backed by a liberal bond issue, county appropriations and Federal aid, is now building hard-surfaced roads in many localities.

EXPLANATION
POPULATION—In the column at the left of the name of the town, under the abbreviation “Pop.” are figures to denote the population.
POST OFFICES of smaller towns are indicated by the abbreviation PO.
COUNTIES—Following the name of the town, is the name of the county in which it is located.
RAILROADS—Railroad towns have the abbreviations of the railroad names. For the explanation of railroad abbreviations, look under the word “Symbol” in the list of “Railroads.”
ELEVATIONS—Below the abbreviation “Alt.” are figures indicating the altitude of the town above sea level.
KEY—The letter and figures in the right hand column under the word “Key” refer respectively to the letter on the top and bottom of the accompanying map and the figures on each side of it; thus indicating the location of the town on the map.
RESOURCES—A brief description gives the industries and resources of important cities.
HOTELS AND BANKS—Under the cities are given the names of one or more hotels. The name of a bank is given under larger banking cities.

KINGDOM
llALY.
•8,QQQ feet. Other summits* continued in the same direction, ■though more distinguished for their classic associations than their elevation, attain in Cithseron, Parries, Pentelicus and Hyniettus the respective bights of 4,630, 4,640, 3,640 and 3,370 feet. Another range, to the north of the former and nearly parallel to it, stretches longitudinally through the island of .Euboea, and in the Delphi Mountains, not far from the north-cast coast, attaining the bight of 5,400 feet; and several other summits of this range exceed 3,000 feet. Quitting northern Gl •eece, a branch from Mount Cithaeron proceeds across the Isthmus of Corinth into the Morea, and stretches over it in all directions. Many of the summits exceed 5,000 feet; and Tay-getus, west of ancient Sparta, forming part of the range which proceeds south to the extremity of the Morea, attains in its culminating point, Makryno or St. Elias, 7,829 feet. Owing to the nature of the surface, the rivers are more remarkable for their number than for their importance. The largest is the Aspropotamos (.Archeldus), which rises in Albania, on the west slope of the Pindus, flows south-south-west through the west part of Livadia, and falls into the Ionian Sea opposite to the isle of Ithaca. The only others deserving of notice—not so much on their own account, as of the interesting associations connected with them—are the Hell a da or Sperchius, the Gav-rioz or .Boeotian Cephissus, the Cephissus of Attica, the Ilissus, all likewise in Livadia; and the Rouphia or Alplieus, and the Eurotas, in the Morea. The climate is generally mild, and in the southern part of the Morea, and in the islands, remarkably equable In the lower regions, winter can not be considered as lasting beyond two mouths. Summer is extremely warm, but is tempered by breezes from the sea. At this season, rain scarcely ever falls. The rainy season occurs after harvest, and the streams which had been dried up, not only fill their channels, but oftentimes overflow them, and in this way stagnant pools are frequently formed, the miasms arising from which are the sources of pestilence, and even of the plague.
Productive Industry.—Greece is an agricultural and pastoral country, and agriculture employs the greater part of the inhabitants. Besides grain, the principal products are currants, wine, olive oil, silk and a variety of fruit. The grain crops consist principally of wheat, barley and maize. Manufactures are extremely limited, and are chiefly confined to clothing and articles of domestic use. In some of the larger towns there are manufactures of wool, cotton and silk, and to these may be added embroideries in gold, silver, silk, etc., and earthenware, leather, harness, cutlery and fire-arms. But unquestionably the most important branch is ship-building, which is carried on to a considerable extent on various points of the coast and islands. Mticli of the trade carried on is merely coasting; but the foreign trade also is large, having advanced with wond< fful rapidity since the independence of the country was re-established.
Government, etc•—Greece is an hereditary monarchy, established in the line of George of Denmark. By the constitution of 1864, the executive power belongs solely to the king; the legislative power is exercised exclusively by a representative chamber. Justice is administered on the basis of the French civil code, by a supreme court (areios-pagos), which has its seat at Athens; two royal courts {ephiteion), one at Athens and another at Nauplia; 10 courts of primary resort (protodikeion), one in each principal town ; and three commercial courts (emporodikeion), one each at Syra, Patras and Nauplia.
Religion and Education.—The national religion is the Orthodox (noil-united) Greek, the government of which is vested in the Holy Synod. The hierarchy consists of a metropolitan, 10 archbishops and 13 bishops. The Roman Catholics in Greece have two archbishops and four bishops. The private exercise of ail other religions is permitted. Public schools are general throughout the kingdom, and their expenses are partly paid by the state. Gymnasia are established in each chief town, and at Athens the National University. In modern times no great name has illustrated Greek literature.
Cities, Towns, etc.—Athens, the capital, and one of the most celebrated cities of the world, is situated about five miles north-east of the Gulf of JEgina. The principal public buildings are the royal palace, the mint, the hospital and the barracks. The antiquities of the city, however, constitute its great attraction. The ancient Acropolis or citadel is still in good preservation, and the remains of numerous temples are strewn over a large extent of ground, both within and without the walls. Port Leone (anc. Piraeus), 5 miles below the city, consists of a land-locked basin, deep to the water’s edge. This is the port of Athens, with which communication is made over an excellent road. Nauplia, on the east side of the gulf of the same name, was the capital previous to 1834. It is a well-built city, fortified and has a fine harbor. Nearly all the trade of the Morea centers here. Corinth, on the isthmus of the same name, has long been an entrepot for the commerce of Greece. The citadel, called Acrocorynthos, on a hill 1,80 ) feet high, is one of the strongest fortresses of the kingdom. Patras is a considerable town on the north-west coast of Achaia. Navarino, on the south-west coast of Messenia, is a fortified town near the southern entrance of the noble basin formed by the island of Sphaji. >Sparta, so renowned in history, is situated on a plain near the right bank of the Basilipotamo. Besides these, there are numerous other noted places, and many of the islands contain cities of considerable pretensions. Ruins of cities are seen in every direction.
History.—The original inhabitants of Greece consisted of various tribes, now generally classed under the common name of Pelasgi. These were supplanted by the Hellenes, apparently a people from the East, who first arrived in the country about b. c. 1384. Little is known relative to this race to the
time of the Trojan war, in b. c. 1184—the whole previous period being designated the Heroic Age—and the most authentic records relating to it must be sought in the poems of Homer. Some centuries later Greece, excepting Sparta, is found divided into a number of independent republics. The mutual jealousies of these states led to the Persian war, and the leaguing of the whole against the foreign enemy. The first great battle, fought at Marathon, b. c. 490, was the commencement of a series of • glorious victories, which issued in the complete defeat of the Persians. During the two following centuries all the great writers, orators, sculptors and architects of Greece appeared ; and it was not only able to repel attacks on its own independence, but to assume the offensive. But, as usual, prosperity proved more trying than adversity had been ; wealth introduced luxury, and the process of degeneracy begun. Ancient jealousies were revived, and state armed against state, each in its turn invoking foreign aid. While the Greeks were thus wasting their energies, Philip of Macedon was calmly devising plans for their subjugation, and, had not death overtaken him, must shortly have made himself as absolute master of the destinies of Greece as his son Alexander afterward became. The power of the Macedonian sovereigns continued permanent in Gi •eece till the Roman Conquest, b. c. 146 ; and the early independent spirit of the nation appeared now to be completely broken. Centuries of degradation rolled over the nation. The crowning disaster commenced a. d. 1438, when the Turks first obtained a footing. A long series of exterminating wars en-sued, during which the Venetians and Turks contended for the mastery. The latter ultimately prevailed, and in 1718 the highest honor which Greece could claim was that of being a Turkish province. Nearly a century of the grossest misrule followed. In 1821, however, when degradation seemed to have reached its lowest possible limit, a strong re-action commenced, a new spirit began to appear, and the Greeks, as if throwing off their lethargy, declared their determination to be free. A protracted struggle ensued, but the issue was still doubtful, when the great European powers interfered, and compelled the Turks in 1829 to acknowledge Greece as an independent state, and in 1844 it was erected into a constitutional monarchy, with Otho, second son of the King of Bavaria, as king. The present ruler, George I., son of the King of Denmark, was elected king by the national assembly, March, 1863.
THE IONIAN ISLANDS
(how united with Greece).
Astronomical Position.—Between latitudes 35° 48' and 39° 55/ north, and longitudes 18° 35/ and 23° IS' east from Greenwich.
boundaries.—The Ionian Islands are bounded on all sides by the Ionian Sea, and are situated off the coast of Albania and the west and south shores of Greece, the most southerly, Cerigo, being off the south extremity of the Morea.
Dimensions, etc.—The aggregate area of the 7 islands composing this group, with their dependencies, is estimated at 1,097 square miles.
Physical Aspect.—The Ionian Islands belong to the same great calcareous formation which prevails over. Greece. They are extremely mountainous, and contain comparatively but a small portion of arable land. The climate generally assimilates that of the adjoining continent, except that the sea renders it more uniformly temperate and humid.
Productive Industry.—Agriculture, although yet ex tremely rude, is the great occupation of the people^and only about the half extent of the islands is under cultivation. The vine, currant and olive are the principal objects of culture. Of grain, comparatively a small quantity is produced. Live stock is abundant, especially sheep and goats. Currants are grown only in Cephalonia, Zante, Santa Maura and Ithaca, but chiefly in the first two islands. Salt is produced in Zante and Santa Maura. In the islands of Corfu and Zante large quantities of soap are manufactured, and also much earthenware. The other manufactures of the islands consist of silk shawls, linens, woolens, and goat-hair carpets and sacking. The staple exports are oil, currants, valonia, wine, soap and salt; and the imports, manufactured goods, grain, etc.
Go vernment, etc.—Each island province is a nome of Greece, except Cerigo, which was united with the nomarchi of Laconia. The established religion is that of the Eastern Greek Church, to which four-fifths of the people belong.
Education.—At Corfu is a university, and also a seminary for priests of the Greek Church. In each of the islands there is a secondary school, maintained at the public expense, in which ancient Greek and Latin, and the modern Greek, English and Italian languages, arithmetic and elementary mathematics are taught. In the chief town of each island is a central school, supported at the public expense, for reading, writing and arithmetic, and for training the village schoolmasters, and there are besides these numerous district schools. The whole is under an inspector-general, subject to a commission for public instruction.
Cities, Towns, etc.— Corfu is situated on the cast side of the island of the same name. It is a fortified town, with narrow and irregular streets and contains a cathedral, several Greek and Catholic churches, the university, etc. The harbor is safe and commodious, and Corfu is the principal seat of the foreign trade of the islands. Cayo is the only important town, and the most frequented harbor in Paxo. Amaxichi, the chief town of Santa Maura, has some manufactures of cotton and leather, and a considerable trade. Vathi, in Ithaca, is a small town with a good harbor. Argostoli, in Cephalonia, is located on a peninsula on the east shore of the gulf to which it gives
(79)
name. The city is meanly built, but the harbor is considered the best in the Ionian Islands, and has several dock-yards. The inner haven or port affords excellent shelter. Cotton goods and pottery are manufactured, and it has an active commerce. liixuri, on the opposite side of the gulf, is another considerable town, with about 6,000 inhabitants. Zante, on the eastern side of the island of the same name, is a large town with an imposing appearance, and has been termed “fore di lev ante”—the flower of the Levant. It is the seat of a considerable commerce. Kapsali is a sea-port on the south shore of Cerigo, and has a commodious harbor. Many of these towns have at various times suffered from earthquakes, which are frequent.
History.—The Ionian Islands, so called from lying in that part of the Mediterranean anciently known as the Mare Ioni-cum or Ionian Sea, often figure in the history of ancient Greece, but only singly, not collectively. They belonged successively to Corinth, Greece, Epirus and Rome. On the fall of the Eastern empire they passed into the hands of the Venetians. In 1797 the French became masters, and labored with assiduity in spreading their democratic principles. In 1800 Russia and Turkey having, by their combined forces, expelled the French, while retaining a protectionate, left the inhabitants to make an attempt at self-government. Anarchy and confusion were the result; and in 1800 Russia, by a secret article in the treaty of lilsit, ceded the islands to France. In 1809—10 all the islands were overrun by the British troops except Corfu, which also surrendered in 1814; and the possession of the British was finally fixed by the treaty of Paris in 1815. After holding the
years (until 1864), the British ceded them to Greece, of which monarchy they now constitute an integral part.
KINGDOM OF ITALY.
Astronomical Position.—Between latitudes 36° 35' and 47° 05' north, and longitudes 6° 21' and 13° 40'east from Greenwich.
Boundaries.—Northern, Switzerland and the Tyrol ; eastern, Illyria and the Adriatic Sea; south-eastern, the Ionian Sea; and south-western and western, the Mediterranean Sea and the French Territory.
% Dimensions—The greatest length of Italy, in a direction north-west and south-east, is near iy 700 miles. The width varies greatly: in the north it is about 320 miles, while in the peninsular portion it nowhere measures more than 160 miles. The area is about 114,300 square miles.
Outline, Coasts, etc.—The general configuration of Italy, as portrayed on the map, bears a striking resemblance to a boot—the widest part in the north forming the mouth, the central portion the leg, and the southern the foot. So exact is the resemblance, that even the spur of the boot has its representative in the projection occupied chiefly by Monte Angelo ; while the heel is seen in the peninsula which is interposed between the Adriatic and the Gulf of Taranto.
The length of the coast has been roughly estimated at 2,000 miles. It is not much broken. The whole shore of the Adriatic presents a comparatively smooth and continuous line, interrupted only by the spur already referred to, which, by its south side, contributes to form the Gulf of Manfredonia. The largest gulf is that of Taranto. The west coast, though much more indented than the east, is more remarkable for the number and occasionally for the beauty of its bays, than for their magnitude. The east shore is generally flat and uninteresting, presenting, particularly along its north part, a long series of sandy islands and lagoons, which retard the progress of the rivers, dam up their mouths, and, depriving them of a proper outlet, occasion the formation of pestilential marshes.
Surface, etc.—The interior is finely diversified. The loftiest mountains of the Alps stand on its frontiers, and shelter it from the rigors of the north, giving it a climate which, though not free from the disadvantages of an oppressive summer heat in the lower valleys and plains, is unrivaled for the general mildness of its temperature and the brightness of its sky. In immediate connection with the branch of the Maritime Alps is the chain of the Apennines, which, first proceeding east till the Adriatic is approached, turn south and traverse the peninsula centrally through its whole length to the Strait of Messina; while numerous branches are thrown offlaterally and form an endless succession either of loftier hills clothed with forests, or gentler slopes covered with olives and vines. In the north, inclosed between the ranges of the Alps and Apennines, is a plain of vast extent, stretching from the west frontiers of Piedmont across Lombardy to the shores of the Adriatic. This plain, though not the largest, is unquestionably the most fertile in Europe, and is capable of furnishing subsistence to a larger population than any other portion of the continent of the same size.
Rivers and Lakes.—The river Po is the only one of magnitude of which Italy can boast. It has the advantage of pursuing its course between the Alps and the Apennines^ and deriving its supplies from both of them. Another river, of some importance, which lias its mouth at no great distance from the former and is partly fed in the same way, is the Etsch, or Adige. In the south part of Italy, the peninsula of which it consists is not only narrow of itself, but is divided by the central chain of the Apennines into two watersheds, each of which lies so near the shore as to leave no room for the formation of large rivers. If the streams descend directly from the mountains to the shore, their course is necessarily so short as

transcription:
K4150 1923 .K46 INDEX TO IOWA, WITH OFFICIAL 1920 CENSUS, AND SHIPPING AND POSTAL GUIDE
EXPLANATION OF INDEX.
Key numbers are in parentheses, thus (DO).
County Seats in capitals, thus ABILENE.
Money Order Postoffices are shown thus •.
Railroads shown by italic figures, thus 17, 34.
Telegraph offices are shown thus O.
The letter and numeral in parentheses directly following the name of the town correspond to the letters and numerals on the margin of the map. To locate a given town trace a line between the given letter on opposite sides of the map and one between the given numeral on opposite sides of the map and at or very near the junction of these lines will be found the town desired.
Italic figures following the key numbers indicate the railroad or railroads upon which the town is situated.

PROSPECTIVE HOMESEEKERS SHOULD VISIT NORTH DAKOTA
North Dakota, a great agricultural state, is the land of opportunity for ambitious men and women of moderate means who want to own a farm home. Business men and farmers have created this organization to extend an invitation to farmers and their families in other states to motor into North Dakota this summer and see’ this country first hand. We will plan your trip to North Dakota in detail.

“A Great Agricultural State*’
Red Tomahawk
Red Tomahawk, the Sioux Indian Chief, killed Sitting Bull at Grand River, South Dakota, during the Ghost Dance outbreak December 15,1890. The gun used was presented by Red Tomahawk to Marshall Ferdinand Foch when he visited North Dakota in 1922. At the same time this friend of the white man smoked the pipe of peace with the great French war hero.
In honor to the man who made the trails of the west safe for the white man, Red Tomahawk’s profile is used as the insignia of the North Dakota Highway Commission in marking highways thruout North Dakota.
U. S. Customs Offices:
Pembina. Neche, Walhalla. Mowbrav (Maida.) Hannah, Sarlcs, Hansboro, St. John, Souris, Westhope, Antler, Sherwood, Northgate, Portal, Ambrose, Crosby, Fortuna.
Canadian Customs Offices:
Emerson, Gretna, Haskett, Snowflake, Crystal City, Cartwright, Killarney, Bannerman, Boissevain, Deloraine, Was-kada in Manitoba, and Elmore, Northgate, North Portal, Es-tevan and Marienthal in Saskatchewan.
Tourists Entering the United States
Will be permitted to remain for a period of 90 days without formal entry upon proper report being made at the port of entry. Owners of automobiles brot in for more than 90 days must furnish bond for the exportation of the car within six months from the date of importation. Tourists should report to U. S. immigration officers for clearance as well as to the United States customs.
Tourists Entering Canada
Should hhve identification papers for Canadian immigration officers. Tourist entering Canada in automobile should report first to the United States customs office to obtain papers for his return to the United States and then to the Canadian immigration and customs officials to secure permit for automobile to enter Canada. On return to the United States he must return permit to Canadian customs officer and then report to the United States customs and immigration officers.

SAINT LOUIS, MO-ILL THE TOPOGRAPHIC MAPS OF THE UNITED STATES
The United States Geological Survey is making a standard topographic atlas of the United States. This work has been inprogress since 1882, and its results consist of published maps of more than 42 per cent of the country, exclusive of outlying possessions.
This topographic atlas is published in the form of maps on sheets measuring about 16^ by 20 inches. Under the general plan adopted the country is divided into quadrangles bounded by parallels of latitude and meridians of longitude. These ' quadrangles are mapped on different scales, the scale selected for each map being that which is best adapted to general use in the development of the country, and consequently, though the standard maps are of nearly uniform size, they represent areas of different sizes. On the lower margin of each map. are printed graphic scales showing distances in feet, meters, and miles. In addition, the scale of the map is shown by a fraction expressing a fixed ratio between linear measu "ements on the map and corresponding distances on the ground. For example, the scale means that 1 unit on the map (such as 1 inch, 1 foot, or 1 meter) represents 62,500 similar units on the earth’s surface.
Although some areas are surveyed and some maps are Compiled and published on special scaleg for special purposes, the standard topographic surveys for the United States proper and the resulting maps have for many years been divided into three, types, differentiated as follows:
1.	Surveys of areas in which there are problems of great public importance—relating, for example, to mineral develop- . ment, irrigation, or reclamation of swamp areas—-are made with sufficient accuracy to be used in the publication of maps on a scale of stiso (1 inch = one-half mile), with a contour interval of' 1, 5, or 10 feet.
2.	Surveys of areas in which there are problems of average • public importance, such as‘most of the basin of the Mississippi -and its tributaries* arq made with sufficient accuracy to be used in the publication of maps pn a scale of (1 inch—nearly
1 mile), with a contour interval of 10 to 25 feet.
3.	Surveys of areas in which the problems are of minor public importance, such as much of. the mountain of desert i region of Arizona or New Mexico, are made with sufficient accuracy to be used in. the publication of maps on a scale of i^ooo (1 inch = nearly 2 miles), with a contour interval of 25 to ' 100 feet.
A topographic survey-of . Alaska has been in progress since 1898, and nearly 43 per cent of its area has now-beetf mapped. About 10 per cent of the Territory has been cbvered by reconnaissance maps on a scale of 6lA_, or about 10 ,miles to an" inch. Most of the remaining area surveyed in Alaska lias been mapped on a scale of but about 4,1)00 square miles has been mapped on a scale of or larger..,
The Hawaiian Islands,,* with the exception of the small islands at the western end of the group, have been surveyed, and the resulting maps are published on a scale of g^oo*
The features shown on these maps may be arranged in three groups—(1) water, including seas, lakes, rivers, canals, swamps, and other bodies of water; (2) relief, including mountains, hills, valleys, and other features of the land surface; (3) culture
(works of man), such as towns, cities, roads, railroads, and boundaries. The symbols used to represent these features are shown and explained below. Variations appear on some earlier maps, and additional features are represented on some special maps.
All the water features are represented in blue, the smaller streams and canals by single blue lines and the larger streams, the lakes, and the sea by blue water lining or blue tint. Intermittent streams—-those whose beds are dry for a large part of the year—are shown by lines of blue dots and dashes.
Relief is shown by contour lines in brown, which on some .maps are supplemented by shading showing the effect of light thrown from the northwest across the area represented, for the purpose of giving the appearance of relief and thus aiding in the interpretation of the contour lines. A contour line represents an imaginary line on the ground (a contour) every part of which is at the same altitude above sea level. Such a line could be drawn at any altitude, but in practice only the con- • tours at certain regular intervals of altitude are shown... The line of the seacoast itself is a contour, the datum or zero of altitude being mean sea level. The 20-foot contour would be the
shore line if the sea should rise 20 feet. Contour lines show
- • * v .	* *
the shape of the hills, mountains, and valleys, as well as their altitude. Successive corpour lines that are far apart qn the map indicate a gentle slope; lines that are.close together indi-. cate a steep slope; and lines that run together indicate a cliff. -
The manner, in which contour lines express altitude, form,. and grade is shown in the figure, below.	-
•C
The sketch represents a river valley that lies between two hills. In the foreground is the sea, with a bay that is partly inclosed by a hooked sand bar. On each side of. the valley is
,	-	.	I'	‘	*.
a terrace into which small streams have cut narrow ? gullies. The hill on the right has a rounded summit and gently slop-
ing spurs separated by ravines. The spurs are truncated at their lower ends by a sea cliff. The hill at the left terminates abruptly at the valley in a steep scarp, from which it slopes gradually away and forms an inclined table-land that is traversed by a few shallow gullies. On the map each of these features is represented, directly beneath its position in the sketch, by contour lines.
The contour interval, or the vertical distance in feet between one contour and the next, is stated at the bottom of each map. This interval differs according to the topography of the area mapped: in a flat country it may be as small as 1 foot; in a mountainous region it may be as great as 250 feet. Certain contour lines, every fourth or fifth one, are made’ heavier than the others and are accompanied by figures showing altitude. The heights of many points—such as road corners, summits, surfaces of lakes, and bench marks—are also given on the map in figures, which show altitudes to the nearest foot only. More exact altitudes—those of bench marks—as well as the geodetic coordinates of triangulation stations, are published in bulletins issued by the Geological Survey.	” •	/ ,
Lettering and the works of man "are shown in black. Boundaries, such as those of a State, county, city, land grant, township, or reservation, are shown by continuous or broken , lines of different kinds and weights. Good motor or public roads are shown by fine double lines, poor motor or private roads by dashed double lines, trails by dashed single lines.
Each quadrangle is designated by the name of a city; town, or prominent natural feature within it, and oh the margins of the map are printed the names of adjoining quadrangles of which maps have been published. Over 3,300 quadrangles in the United States have been surveyed, and maps of them similar to the one on the other side of this sheet have been published.
The topographic map is the base on which the geology-and mineral resources of a quadrangle are represented, and the maps showing these features are bound together with a descriptive text to form a folio of the Geologic Atlas of thq United
,
States. More than 220 folios have been published.
Index maps of each State and of Alaska and Hawaii showing the areas covered by topographic maps and geologic folios published by the United States Geological Survey may be obtained free. Copies of the standard topographic maps may be obtained for 1(> cents each ; some special maps are sold at different prices. A discount of 40 per cent is allowed on an order for maps amounting to •$5 or more at the retail price. The geologic folios are sold for 25 cents or more each, the price depending on the size of the folio. A circular describing the folios will be sent on request.	:
Applications for maps or folios should be accompanied by
cash, draft, or money order (not postage stamps) and should be
* " r •
addressed to
THE DIRECTOR,
United States Geological Survey,
Washington, D. C.
September, 1928.

transcription:
rpi
HE TOPOGRAPHIC MAPS OF T

’TT
ED
The United States Geological Survey is making a standard topographic atlas of the United States. This work has been. in progress since 1882, and its results consist of published maps of more than 40 per cent of the country, exclusive of outlying possessions.
This topographic atlas is published in the form of maps on sheets measuring about 18.i- by 20 inches. Under the general plan adopted the country is divided into quadrangles bounded by parallels of latitude- and meridians of longitude. These quadrangles are mapped on different scales, the scale selected for each map being that which is best, adapted to general use in the development of the country, and consequently, though the standard maps are of nearly uniform size, they represent areas of different sizes. On the lower margin of each map are printed graphic scales showing distances in feet, meters, and miles. In addition, the scale of the map is shown by a fraction expressing a fixed ratio between linear measurements on the map and corresponding distances on the ground. For example, the scale 5^55 means that X unit on the map (such as i inch. 1 foot, or 1 meter) represents 82,500 similar units on the earth’s surface.
Although some areas are surveyed and. some maps are compiled and published on special scales for special purposes, the standard topographic surveys for the U nited States proper and the resulting maps have for many years been divided into three types, differentiated as follows:
1.	Surveys of areas in which there are problems of great
public importance—relating, for example, to mineral development, irrigation, or reclama tion of swamp areas-—are made with sufficient accuracy to be used in the publication of maps on a scale of g— (1 inch —. one-half mile), with a contour interval of 1, 5, or 10 feet.	’
2.	Surveys of areas in which there are problems of average public importance, such as most of the basin of the Mississippi and its tributaries, are made with sufficient accuracy to be used in the publication of maps on a scale of ^ (1 inch—nearly 1 mile), with a contour interval of 10 to 25 feet.
3.	Surveys of areas in which the problems are of minor public importance, such as much of the mountain or desert region of Arizona or New Mexico, are made with sufficient accuracy to be used in the publication of maps on a scale of ~5 (1 inch — nearly 2 miles), with a contour interval of 25 to 100 feet.
A topographic survey of Alaska has been in progress since 1898, and nearly 37 per cent of its area has now been mapped. About 10 per cent of the Territory has been covered by reconnaissance maps on a scale of	or about 10 miles to an
inch. Most of the remaining area surveyed in Alaska has been mapped on a scale of but about 4,000 square miles has been mapped on a scale of
About half of the Hawaiian Islands has been surveved, and the resulting maps are published on a scale of
The features shown on these maps may be arranged in three groups—(1) water, including seas, lakes, rivers, canals, swamps, and other bodies of water: (2) relief, including mountains, hills, valleys, and other features of the land surface; (3) culture (works of man), such as towns, cities, roads, railroads, and
boundaries. The conventional signs used to represent these features are shown and explained below. Variations appear on some earlier maps, and additional features are represented on some special maps.
AH the water features are represented in blue, the smaller streams and canals by single blue lines and the larger streams, the lakes, and the sea by blue water lining or blue tint. Intermittent streams—those whose beds are dry for a large part of the year—are shown by lines of blue dote and dashes.
Relief is shown by contour lines in brown, which on some
9/
maps are supplemented by shading showing the effect of light thrown from the northwest across the area represented, for the purpose of giving the appearance of relief and thus aiding in the interpretation of the contour lines. A contour line represents an imaginary line on the ground (a contour) every part of which is at the same altitude above sea level. Such a line could be drawn at any altitude, but in practice only the contours at certain regular intervals of altitude are shown. The line of the seaeoast itself is a contour, the datum or zero of altitude being mean sea level The 20-foot contour would be the
o
shore line if the sea should rise 20 feet. Contour lines show the shape of the hills, mountains, and valleys, as well as their altitude. Successive contour lines that are far apart on the map indicate a gentle slope; lines that are close together indicate a steep slope: and lines that run together indicate a cliff.
The manner in which contour lines express altitude,' form, and grade is shown in the figure below.

The sketch represents a river valley that lies between two hills. In the foreground is the sea, with a bay that is partly inclosed by a hooked sand bar. On each side of the valley is a terrace into which small streams have cut narrow gullies. The hill on the right has a rounded summit and gently sloping spurs separated by ravines. The spurs are truncated at
their lower ends by a sea cliff. The hill at the left terminates abruptly at the valley in a steep scarp, from which it slopes gradually away and forms an inclined table-land that is, traversed by a few shallow gullies. On the map each of these features is represented, directly beneath its position in the sketch, by contour lines.
The contour interval, or the vertical distance in feet between one contour and the next, is stated at the bottom of each map. This interval differs according to the topography of the area mapped: in a flat country it may be as small as 1 foot; in a mountainous .region it may be as great as 250 feet. Certain contour lines, every fourth or fifth one, are made heavier than the others and are accompanied by figures showing altitude. The heights of many points—such as road corners, summits, surfaces of lakes, and bench marks—are also given on the map in figures, which show altitudes to the nearest foot only. More exact altitudes—those of bench marks—as well as the geodetic coordinates of triangulation stations, are published in bulletins issued by the Geological Survey.
Lettering and the works of man are shown in black. Boundaries, such as those of a State, county, city, land grant, township, or reservation, are shown by continuous or broken lines of different kinds and weights. Metaled roads are shown by double lines, one of which is accentuated. Other public roads are shown by fine double lines, private and poor roads by dashed, double lines, trails by dashed single lines.
Each quadrangle is designated by the name of a city, town, or prominent natural feature within it, and on the margins of the map are printed the names of adjoining quadrangles of which maps have been published. Over 3,000 quadrangles in the United States have been surveyed, and maps of them similar to the one on the other side of tins sheet have been published.
The topographic map is the base on which the geology and mineral resources of a quadrangle are represented, and the maps showing these features are bound together with a descriptive text to form a folio of the Geologic Atlas of the United States. More than 200 folios have been published.
Index maps of each State and of Alaska and Hawaii showing the areas covered by topographic maps and geologic folios published by the United States Geological Survey may be obtained free. Copies of the standard topographic maps may be obtained for 10 cents each; some special maps are sold at different prices. A discount of 40 per cent is allowed on an order for maps amounting to $5 or more at the retail price. The geologic folios are sold for 25 cents or more each, the price depending on the size of the folio. A circular describing the folios will be sent on request.
Applications for maps or folios should be accompanied by cash, draft, or money order (not postage stamps) and should be
o*
addressed to
THE DIRECTOR,
United Slates Geological Survey,
Washington, D. C.
January, 1924.

NORTH DAKOTA

Agricultural
Development Department
Northern Pacific Railway
North Dakota Ranks First Among the States in Sweet Clover Hay and Seed Production.
THERE is no better evidence that North Dakota is overcoming the misinformation which too long branded it as a great plains section subject to the evils of one crop farming than the fact that loans on her farm lands are considered by conservative business men as a sound investment under present conditions.
North Dakota’s recent crop and livestock returns constitute the foundation of a new era which has introduced a reliable mixed agriculture and the climate and soils have demonstrated beyond
question their worth by placing the state well up among the leading states of the Union in production. The lands are in demand. In a recent two-year period, purchases of farms in the state involved a total of 2,250,000 acres. North Dakota, her farms rich in the yields they produce, yet still low in price, is setting new dollar marks in her agricultural history.
Industrially, the state is entering a new period of expansion which should result in greater utilization of her soil and mineral resources.
People generally do not realize the high standing of North Dakota’s farm production with relation to that of other states. Tales have been told and retold by writers seeking color rather than facts to make their stories interesting, and as a result the state has not been pictured in its true light.
PRESENTING THE FACTS
The following table presents the facts. It shows the state ranking first in production of spring wheat, rye, flax, sweet clover hay and sweet clover seed and second in barley. The comparative ranking also of some of the other crops completes an illustration of the riches that the soils now are yielding under a modern type of agriculture along with the lengthy days of warm sunshine and the greatest proportion of the annual rainfall during the growing season.
Rank of North Dakota with Other States in Crop
Production
Crop	1928 Production	Rank of
Spring Wheat			 142,923,000 Bus.	1st
Rye 			 12,710,000	”	1st
Flaxseed 			 8,115,000	”	1st
Barley 			 55,564,000	”	2nd
Oats			 59,954,000	”	7 th
Corn			 24,426,000	”	21st
Potatoes			 14,000,000	”	9 th
All Hay			 3,644,000 Tons	14 th
Sweet Clover Hay .		 608,000 ”	1st
Alfalfa Hay 			 473,000	”	19th
Sweet Clover Seed.		 231,000 Bus.	1st
The total crop production of the state in 192 8, according to the United States department of agriculture, was valued a $242,942,000.
WHERE QUALITY MEANS PROFIT
The high ranking with respect to production of the important feed crops is significant. With nearly a million acres in corn last year, the state continued to hold the new place among cornbelt states which it acquired in more recent years.
Largely because of natural conditions, the quality of spring wheat is high, especially as gauged by the protein content. Growers get more for their wheat because of the premium that millers are willing to pay for a high protein content. In 19 28 nearly 800 different samples of common wheats tested averaged 12.12 per cent protein and more than 3 00 samples of Durum wheats averaged 11.2 per cent.
The high quality of North Dakota products is demonstrated further by the fact that at the last International Grain & Hay Show at Chicago flax produced in Cass County won the grand championship of the World.
The Buffalo Knew His Grasses
From 1919 to 1927 the alfalfa acreage increased 200 per cent. No better evidence of the feeding value and the palatability of North Dakota grasses is given than the preference shown by the buffalo who represents the earliest class of livestock to feed upon the soil products of North Dakota. History relates that the buffalo, of all places in the country that were available for grazing, preferred the prairie of North Dakota. The herds are said to have been more numerous than in any other section of the country. The buffalo grazed where he could obtain the best living.
Today legumes for livestock hay may readily be grown, since the soils are not deficient in limestone, and the acreages of these crops continually are on the increase. They can be produced in any county of the state. Failure due to climatic hazards is remote, as evidenced by the experience of the North Dakota Agricultural Experiment Station in its work with alfalfa.

mands the notice of one considering the state from the standpoint of seeking a new location. It is an increase of $8,981,000 over the year before, due in part to a greater number of sheep and to the increased market value of cattle, although all cattle and calves show a one per cent increase over the previous 12 months.
Below is a table showing the numbers of different classes of livestock on North Dakota farms January 1st, 1929:
Numbers and Value of North Dakota Livestock
Class of Stock	Number of Head	Value
All Cattle ................ 1,078,000	$57,990,000
Milk Cows & Heifers........	454,000	34,050,000
Sheep ..............•...... 582,000	6,434,000
Swine ....................... 587,000	8,819,000
Horses ...................... 589,000	30,771,000
Mules ........................ 10,000	551,000
Total Value all Livestock...................$104,565,000
(From Bureau of Agriculture Economics, U. S. Dept., of Agric.)
Sheep show an increase of more than 270,000 head in the last five years. This is due largely to establishment of more farm flocks, with breeding ewes introduced from mountain sheep producing regions of states further west.
DAIRYING PAYS HERE
Dairying, with the regular monthly cream check that accompanies it, unquestionably has been on the increase. The new Salem Holstein Breeding circuit, in the vicinity of New Salem, in the western part of the state, is a striking example of the possibilities. The circuit in 192 8 had a record of 345.8 pounds of butterfat and 9,529 pounds of milk for 152 head of pure-bred Holstein cows in 16 herds. The highest individual'record was 805.5 pounds of butter-fat and 20,716.1 pounds of milk for one cow. For five years the average of the circuit has been more than 300 pounds of butterfat per cow.
The trend toward more livestock farming is shown in a comparison of the total receipts from the state on the principal markets. In every instance there was a large
