The increases were gradual during the intervening years.
AGRICULTURE IS IMPROVED
Not only is there more livestock, but there is a trend toward an improved class of animals. Since January 1st, 1925, more than 5,000 pure-bred sires with a total value $350,000 have been placed on farms of the state. Such a development speaks for the enterprising and progressive character of the farmers of North Dakota and obviously will result advantageously for them.
North Dakota livestock at the last International Livestock Exposition in Chicago won two championships and a total of more than 30 premiums. That the state can produce a finished product of quality was demonstrated in a recent state baby beef feeding contest from which the first, second and third prize carloads were sold on the St. Paul market from $12.50 to $14.75. The latter price, the top at the time of the sale, was received for the first prize load of 15 baby beeves raised and fattened on the same farm.
The winners in this contest joined in the belief that North Dakota has a future in the baby beef feeding industry.
Contour of Lands Varied
In the eastern part of the state, the Red River Valley, extending westward 25 to 50 miles, is the section frequently referred to as the “Bread Basket of the World.” It has an elevation of 800 to 1,000 feet. The soils vary from loam to clay loam and clay. Relatively small areas bordering the valley on the west are delta soils formed by prehistoric river action. They are light loam to sandy in character.
Next come the rolling prairies of central and northern North Dakota. The elevation is from 1,300 to 1,600 feet and the soils consist chiefly of loam, silt loam and light clay loam. It is known as the drift area.
To the west, covering in general the western part of the state, is an immense territory rich in its plant foods, known as the Missouri plateau. It has an elevation ranging from 1,300 to 2,400 feet. The eastern and northern parts of this section consist of very fertile loam soils, somewhat hilly. The southwest portion of this area is of erosion formation consisting of loam, sandy loam, clay loam aijd clay. Outcroppings of sandstone, shale rock and lignite coal, occur in the hills and buttes and along the streams. This section is in contrast to the prairie country and has highly productive soils that are easily tilled.
A strip of country about 15 miles wide through the Missouri plateau from northwest to southeast is known as the Altamont moraine. Rather abrupt hills and ridges interspersed by areas of undulating prairie occur here. The soils are loams and clays, although glacial rock is more evident than elsewhere.
In the southwestern section of the state, the soils are formed by erosion rather than glacial action. In the extreme western portion bordering the Little Missouri River is a rough section, useful principally for grazing, although many of the small fertile valley flats are tilled. This is North Dakota’s “bad lands” area, marked by a strange jumble of fantastically shaped hills, buttes and colored rocks.
The Climate Has Advantages
How the climate appeals to the farmer was summed up by Garnet Elliott, a resident of the Red River Valley when he said, “As to climate, I do not think there is any place to beat North Dakota. It is true we get some cold winters, but they are the exception. The dry atmosphere makes it a healthful place for livestock production. I spent one winter in California and came back to North Dakota to build up a real home.”
The $1,500,000 Sugar Beet Factory, at East Grand Forks, Is a Sure Cash
Market for Red River Valley Beets.
This Central North Dakota Corn Is Typical—Rather Small Stalk Yet Leafy and Producing a Large Number of Average Sized Ears. The Crop Is an Important Item in the Expanding Livestock Industry.
North Dakota’s frost-free season is lengthy. It varies in different sections from 111 to 13 6 days, while a large area of approximately half of the state has a frost-free period of from 121 to 125 days.
After the first killing frost in the fall, usually in late September, the farmers enjoy a period of several weeks of balmy weather, the famous “Great Plains Indian Summer.” This offers an excellent opportunity to complete fall work. Hot, muggy days in summer are very rare and the long twilight periods and nights are cool. State authorities claim approximately 20 0 hours more sunshine during the growing season than obtains in Ohio, Indiana, Illinois or Iowa, which contributes toward rapid growth and early maturity of crops in North Dakota. The principal crops rarely, if ever, are damaged by frost.
Greatest Rainfall in Growing Season
Weather .bureau records over a period of years show the average rainfall for the entire state to be about 17 inches. It varies from over 24 inches in the eastern part of the state to about 15 to 17 inches in western North Dakota.
It is significant that more than three quarters of the annual rain comes during the six months, April 1st to September 30th. Almost half of it comes during May, June and July. Such a distribution provides by far the greater portion of the moisture during the time of the year when it does the most good for crops. This situation coupled with the fact that contour of the country and the physical condition of the soil are such that there is very little “run-off” of rainfall makes the average yearly precipitation, in the main, sufficient. Furthermore, low surface evaporation and the moisture-holding properties of both surface and subsoil make a large percentage of the moisture available for crops.

‘White River, South Dakota
Witten, South Dakota
Norris, South Dakota
Auctioneer
Witten is one of the most prosperous and thriving inland towns in the Rosebud Country. It is located on Cottonwood Creek, 18 miles northwest of Winner, S. D.
i
White River is the County Seat of Mellette County. It is an inland town of 500 people, having the only municipally owned hydro-electric plant in the state. Has churches, schools and every business enterprise found in towns many times its size. Abundance of soft water is obtained from Little White River.
The soil is rich and grows in abundance anything that is planted. Particular attention is paid to alfalfa. The seed crop alone in one year will (pay for the land on which it is grown. Water in abundance can be obtained in any part of the county.
The town is surrounded by many thousands of acres of choicest Indian allotment lands which are offered for sale at stated intervals by the Rosebud Indian Agency. Most of this land can be bought on installment payments under government regulations.
There is a splendid market at White River for cream, butter, eggs and poultry and the prices obtained are as good as can be obtained at any of the railroad towns in the vicinity. Retail prices at White River are just as low and in many instances lower than prices at the surrounding railroad towns. Stocks of goods kept here compare favorably with railroad towns and the farmer can obtain practically everything that he can obtain at the railroad.
Star and rural mail routes serve every part of the County. The rural schools are maintained at a high standard, many being state aid schools.

Registered Professional Civil Engineer and Land Surveyor
PUBLISHER OF THIS MAP
25 YEARS IN THE ROSEBUD COUNTRY Plats and appraisals made on any tract of land in this country. Wall maps of the Rosebud postpaid $1.50.
For any information regarding the Rosebud Country, write me.
Are Wonder Routes to the
LANDS, LOANS, INSURANCE
Blackpipe Valley, which is one of the most fertile regions of South Dakota, lies in the Rosebud country. Crop failures are unknown. There are ideal living conditions, with plenty of good water—one thing so essential to this West River country.
Memorial State Highway No. 40 passes through Witten. This highway connects the Milwaukee and North Western railroads, thus giving as good mail and bus service as is enjoyed by railroad towns.
Breeder of Pure Bred Hampshire Hogs.
Winner, S. D.
BLACK HILLS
Winner, S. D.
Witten’s citizenship is reflected by its accredited high school, fine churches, tine stores, and strong bank. It is surrounded by a fertile valley where alfalfa and corn is king.
Well located on good graded roads that stretch in every direction is found the thriving town of Norris. Every day is business day, and the Blackpipe State Bank (the only bank in this valley), the three general stores, meat market, garage, blacksmith shop, restaurant, two cream stations, barber shop, pool hall, and post office are wide awake institutions. They realize the opportunities of this golden spot and are doing everything in their power to help develop this Land of Promise.

grows the corn—come and see.
Twenty years ago this vast country was prairie land and uninhabited, not a furrow turned. Today it is the home of 40,000 prosperous contented farmers and there is room for as many more honest to goodness farmers. It is a vast undeveloped empire. Right now land can be purchased cheaper than it ever will be again and this same land at merely a little greater than rental prices will produce almost as much as the high priced land where you are. Are you satisfied with your surroundings? If not, come to the Rosebud look and investigate for yourself. We know if you do this, you will be one of us. Opportunity is knocking at your door—crank up the jitney, take a trip to the Hills over the Black Hills Highway No. 50 or the Memorial Highway No. 40 and see the Rosebud Country.
Do you know that in 1921 Todd, a county in the Rosebud, took first on County exhibit at the Inter-State Fair at Sioux City. In fact, scored 247 points above Woodbury County in this department. The same year their wheat took first at the State Fair in Huron, and also in 1921 the Rosebud Chester White hog, Prince Anak, took the blue ribbon at Huron, South Dakota State Fair also at the Inter-State Fair, Sioux City, and won Grand Championship of the world at the National Hog Show, and this on Rosebud alfalfa which is raised without innoculation of the soil. Many statements of this kind could be made if space permitted, as each and every portion of the Rosebud is a world beater. Last year out of the towns on the C. & N. W. Ry. in the Rosebud, were shipped 4,707,760 pounds of cream, 1,597 cars of cattle, 3,033 cars of hogs, 2,365 cars of corn, 1,282 cars of small grain, 62 cars of poultry, 1, 869,000 dozens of eggs and this only from a small portion of the Rosebud. The C. M. & St. Paul Ry., on the north and the C. & N. W. Ry., Omaha-Casper line on the south, both take a large amount of stock and produce out of the Rosebud, but no statistics are on hand and remember also that this country is only a little better than half tilled, the greater portion of Indian and State lands being leased for grazing only.
Hog raising, poultry and dairying are fast coming to the front, in fact, take the lead in this country.
MR. HOMESEEKER, all we want is a chance to show you, and again we ask that you take your trip this year via the Black Hills Highway No. 50 or the Memorial Highway No. 40 and investigate the Famous Rosebud Country.

market at reasonable rates.

State, includes Gregory, Tripp, Mellette and Todd Counties. It lies only loO miles northwest of Sioux City, Iowa, and 225 miles northwest of Omaha, Nebr., just west of the Missouri River, and the north line of the State of Nebraska is its south boundary.
The rainfall in the Rosebud, as shown by Government rain gauge at Fort Randall, is only a fraction of an inch below that of Sioux City, Iowa, over a period of forty years and this rain is mostly during the growing season.
The winters are usually very mild and the summers delightful, with cool evenings, the altitude averaging 2,000 feet.
The soil of this vast empire is mostly a black loam with some heavier clays in the northern portion. It is practically all underlaid with a clay formation sub-soil, the greatest ub-soil in the world for farming purposes and the top soil on farm land is from 28 inches to 40 inches deep.
The country is blessed with an abundant supply of water, most of which can be obtained at a depth of 15 to 60 feet. It is pure, cold, soft water in most localities and the northeastern part of the Rosebud is in the artesian belt.■■The Natural water supply is abundant, also, the White River, the Keya Paha River and Little White River with many other smaller streams, which flow the year around furnish this country with more natural supply than is found in any other section of the state. The Little White River has one Hydro-Electric plant now, and surveys are being made at this time for very extensive development of this stream.

A ROSEBUD FARMER RELATES SUCCESS.
Winner, Tripp County, S. D.
You have asked me to give you my experience in Tripp County.
1 liled on a homestead when the county was opened to settlement and moved my family on the claim in 1909, built a small house 16x32, and sheds for m-y st0,1k wiricli consisted of spij cows, ten head of Horses, and six brood sows.
The first year 1 broke out about 130 acres and have been farming and raising hogs and cattle since.
My crops have been light some years but generally very good. One year my corn only made 15 bushels to the acre, but other years has averaged 3 0 to 5 0 bushels. 1 sow some fall wheat every year which yielded from 30 to 50 bushels, my barley has run from 3 0 to 5 0 bushels, oats from 35 to 75 and rye from 2 0 to 4 3 bushels to the acre; this is the smallest and best yields.
I sowed 40 acres of alfalfa in 1910, the first three years 1 cut it twice a year, but since have been cutting it 3 and 4 times, it now will cut about 5 tons to the acre a year.
I now own 8 80 acres of land, with a modern 9-room house, good barn 40x5 6 and other good buildings, 162 head of cattle, 41 head of horses, 102 hogs. All clear of encumbrance.
For the past live years I have been selling produce from my farm, including cattle and hogs, amounting to from $10,000 to $13,000 every year.
1 know of no country I could have gone to and done as well as I have in Tripp county. 1 believe ihe ‘Ttosebud Country” is equal to any.
JOSEPH NOVOTNY.

This country, although only a few years old, has a wonderful system of highways. Take a look at the map on the reverse side. See the network of County and State highways, not trails, but all graded highways. The Rosebud is crossed east and west by the famous Black Hills Highway No. 50 and the Memorial State Highway No. 40, both leading from the Rosebud Bridge, across the Missouri River, and the Black Hills Sioux Trail enters at the southeast corner joining Highway No. 50 at Bonesteel. There are numerous State and County highways running north and south, the North and South Pike being the best known at this time. In fact, the Rosebud may be entered from any direction. The streams all have fine bridges and the roads are the best.

Where we have never known a complete crop failure.
Where we have a good black sandy loam soil that will produce croips of any kind that is adapted to this climate.
Where we have good soft water that can be obtained at a depth of from 10 to 60 feet.
Where we have 22 streams of pure spring water which make an ample supply of water for live stock.
Where you can produce pork, beef and butter fat cheaper than you can anywhere on earth.
Where we can sell good farm land on good terms at from $10 to $25 per acre.
Where we have about 25 0 miles of graded highways including State Highway No. 50 which runs through the county east and west.
